pick-and-roll-reads.description: Reading hedge, switch, ice, drop coverage and making correct decisions

questions.scenario: You're running a pick-and-roll with your center. The defender guarding your screener steps out hard to hedge and trap you above the 3-point line.
questions.question: What's your best decision?

options.text: Split the hedge and attack the rim
Back up and reset the play
Pass to your rolling center immediately
Look for the open teammate on the weak side

questions.explanation: When the big hedges hard, your screener should be rolling wide open to the rim with his defender out of position. This is a 4-on-3 situation - get the ball to the roller quickly before help defense can recover.

questions.scenario: The defense switches the pick-and-roll, putting a smaller defender on your big man and their big on you.
questions.question: How should you exploit this mismatch?

options.text: Immediately post up your big man with the smaller defender
Attack the bigger defender guarding you
Look for a quick pass to your big in the post
Reset and run another pick-and-roll

questions.explanation: When they switch, get the ball to your big man quickly in good post position before help defense can come. The size mismatch in the post is usually easier to exploit than trying to beat a big man off the dribble.

questions.scenario: You run pick-and-roll, and the defense 'ices' you by forcing you to the sideline while the big drops back to protect the paint.
questions.question: What's your best counter to this coverage?

options.text: Take the contested 3-pointer from the sideline
Drive hard to the baseline
Hit your screener popping to the mid-range area
Reject the screen and attack the other way

questions.explanation: Ice coverage is designed to force you into a low-percentage shot on the sideline. The best counter is to reject the screen and attack the opposite direction where you have more space and better angles.

questions.scenario: Your screener sets a pick and the defense drops the big man back to protect the rim while your defender fights over the top.
questions.question: What opportunity does this create?

options.text: Drive hard to the rim past the dropping big
Take the open mid-range pull-up jumper
Pass to your rolling big man
Look for the skip pass to the weak side

questions.explanation: Drop coverage gives you the mid-range pull-up jumper. The big is protecting the rim, your defender is fighting over the screen - you have a clean look from 15-18 feet. Take the shot the defense is giving you.

questions.scenario: You're running pick-and-roll and notice the help defender cheating over early to stop your drive, leaving his man open in the corner.
questions.question: What's your read?

options.text: Continue with your drive since you saw it first
Make the skip pass to the open corner shooter
Pull back and look for your rolling big
Call for a different screen

questions.explanation: When help defense rotates early, the skip pass to the open shooter is usually the highest percentage play. Corner 3-pointers are great shots, and the early help means your teammate should be wide open.

questions.scenario: Running a side pick-and-roll near the free-throw line extended. The defense shows two defenders coming at you (your man and the screener's man).
questions.question: What's happening and how do you react?

options.text: It's a trap - look for the open man immediately
Split between the two defenders
Dribble back out to reset
Force a shot over the defense

questions.explanation: When two defenders commit to you in pick-and-roll, it creates a 4-on-3 advantage for your team. Don't fight the trap - find the open teammate quickly. Someone will be wide open.

half-court-offense.description: Reading defenses, creating spacing, ball movement, and offensive flow

questions.scenario: You bring the ball up court and see your team bunched together on one side, with poor spacing.
questions.question: What's your first priority?

options.text: Call a timeout to reset
Drive to the rim immediately
Organize your teammates into proper spacing
Look for a quick shot before defense adjusts

questions.explanation: As the point guard, you're the floor general. Poor spacing leads to easy help defense and turnovers. Use your voice and gestures to spread the floor and create proper spacing before initiating offense.

questions.scenario: Your team is in a 4-out, 1-in set. The defense is sagging off your teammates to help on drives, but your shooters are good 3-point threats.
questions.question: How do you exploit this defensive strategy?

options.text: Keep driving since they're giving you the lane
Make the extra pass to kick out for 3-pointers
Post up your big man since they're helping off him
Call for screens to create better driving lanes

questions.explanation: If the defense is helping off good shooters, make them pay. Drive and kick to your open shooters for 3-pointers. Force the defense to choose: help and give up threes, or stay home and let you drive.

questions.scenario: The shot clock is winding down (under 10 seconds), and your offense hasn't generated a good look yet.
questions.question: What's your responsibility as the point guard?

options.text: Get the ball to your best scorer and let him create
Take the shot yourself - it's your job
Call a quick screen to create something
Look for any available shot to avoid the shot clock violation

questions.explanation: With the shot clock running down, get the ball to your best shot creator in a position where he can score. Don't force a bad shot yourself - your job is to get the best scorer the best opportunity possible.

questions.scenario: You notice the defense is in a 2-3 zone. Your team has good outside shooters and a skilled post player.
questions.question: What's the most effective way to attack this zone?

options.text: Feed the post immediately
Swing the ball side to side to find open shots
Attack the high post/free throw line area
Drive into the gaps of the zone

questions.explanation: The high post is the weak spot in a 2-3 zone. Get the ball to the free throw line area - this forces the zone to collapse and creates open shots on the perimeter or easy passes inside.

questions.scenario: Your team is up by 15 points with 8 minutes left. The defense is pressing and trying to create chaos.
questions.question: How should you manage the offense?

options.text: Push the pace to extend the lead
Slow down and run clock
Keep running your normal offense
Look for quick shots to put the game away

questions.explanation: Don't let the defense dictate how you play. With a big lead and time left, stick to your normal offense. Take good shots when they come, but don't change your approach just because they're pressing.

defensive-recognition.description: Identifying zone vs man, help positioning, rotations, and defensive adjustments

questions.scenario: At the start of a possession, you want to quickly determine if the defense is in man-to-man or zone coverage.
questions.question: What's the best way to identify the defensive scheme?

options.text: Look at how defenders guard the post player
Motion a player across the court and see if his defender follows
Drive to see how the help defense reacts
Look at the initial defensive alignment

questions.explanation: Motion is the quickest and most reliable way to identify coverage. If the defender follows the motion, it's man-to-man. If he stays in his area while another defender picks up the motion, it's zone coverage.

questions.scenario: You're driving to the basket and see the help defender starting to rotate over from the weak side.
questions.question: What should you be thinking?

options.text: Challenge the help and try to score through contact
Pull up for a mid-range jumper
Find the open teammate that the help left behind
Continue driving and see what happens

questions.explanation: When help defense comes, someone is getting left open. As the point guard, find that open player and get him the ball. Don't fight the help - use it to create advantages for your teammates.

questions.scenario: The defense is switching everything - all screens, all cuts, all off-ball movement.
questions.question: How do you exploit a switching defense?

options.text: Look for size mismatches after switches
Set more screens to create confusion
Isolate one-on-one since they're switching
Move the ball quickly before they can switch

questions.explanation: Switching creates mismatches. Look for bigs guarding guards (speed advantage) or guards guarding bigs (size advantage). Find these mismatches quickly and exploit them before help can arrive.

questions.scenario: You notice the defense is 'showing' on every screen - having the screener's defender step out briefly then recover.
questions.question: What does this tell you about their defensive strategy?

options.text: They're trying to force tough shots
They want to disrupt your timing without fully committing
They're setting up for a steal
They're in a zone defense

questions.explanation: Showing is a technique to disrupt the ball handler without fully committing to a hedge or switch. They want to slow you down and make you hesitate, but they're not fully stopping your penetration.

questions.scenario: The defense is playing 'pack line' - staying close to the paint and giving you outside shots but taking away drives.
questions.question: What's the best way to attack this defensive system?

options.text: Take the outside shots they're giving you
Try to drive anyway - be aggressive
Work the ball inside through the post
Use ball screens to create driving lanes

questions.explanation: Pack line defense is designed to take away easy baskets at the rim. If you and your teammates can knock down outside shots, the defense will have to extend and give you driving lanes. Make them pay for the space they're giving you.

fast-break-decisions.description: Reading numbers advantage, trailer reads, pull-up timing, and transition offense

questions.scenario: You secure a defensive rebound and see a 3-on-2 fast break opportunity developing.
questions.question: What's your primary focus pushing the ball up court?

options.text: Get to the rim as fast as possible
Look for the earliest scoring opportunity
Control the pace and make the right read
Get the ball to your fastest player

questions.explanation: In transition, don't rush. Control the pace, read the defense, and make the right play. A 3-on-2 should result in a good shot - either at the rim or a wide-open 3-pointer. Be patient and make the defense commit first.

questions.scenario: You're leading a 2-on-1 fast break. The lone defender is backing up and protecting the paint.
questions.question: What's your best decision?

options.text: Attack the rim and try to score through contact
Pull up for an open 3-pointer
Draw the defender and pass to your teammate
Slow down and wait for more help to arrive

questions.explanation: In a 2-on-1, force the defender to make a choice. Attack him directly to make him commit, then pass to your open teammate for an easy score. Don't settle for a contested shot when you have a numbers advantage.

questions.scenario: You're pushing the ball in transition when you notice a trailing big man filling the lane behind you.
questions.question: How does this trailer affect your decision-making?

options.text: It doesn't - focus on the players ahead of you
Look for him if the initial break doesn't develop
Pass back to him immediately for a 3-pointer
Slow down so he can catch up

questions.explanation: The trailer is your safety valve. If the initial fast break opportunity doesn't materialize (defenders get back, passing lanes are covered), the trailing big man often has an open shot or good post position.

questions.scenario: You have a clear path to the basket in transition, but you notice a defender sprinting back who might challenge your shot.
questions.question: What factors should influence your decision to shoot or pass?

options.text: Always take the layup - you got there first
Your shooting ability vs. the defender's shot-blocking ability
Whether your teammates are in position for a rebound
How much the game situation matters (score, time)

questions.explanation: Assess the matchup. If you're confident in finishing through contact or the defender isn't a strong shot blocker, take the layup. If he's a rim protector and you have open teammates, make the pass for a better shot.

questions.scenario: The fast break opportunity breaks down, but you still have 4-5 seconds of transition offense before the defense gets fully set.
questions.question: What's your approach in this 'secondary break' situation?

options.text: Pull the ball out and set up half-court offense
Look for quick ball movement to find an open shot
Drive immediately before help defense arrives
Call a play to organize your teammates

questions.explanation: In secondary break, the defense isn't fully organized yet. Move the ball quickly to find the open shot - often a 3-pointer or mid-range jumper. Don't waste the advantage by slowing down, but don't force a bad shot either.

clock-management.description: Shot clock awareness, end-of-quarter scenarios, and game situation management

questions.scenario: Shot clock at 8 seconds, and your team hasn't generated a good shot yet. The score is tied with 3 minutes left in the game.
questions.question: What's your priority?

options.text: Get the ball to your best scorer and let him create
Take a quick shot to avoid the violation
Drive to the rim for a high-percentage shot
Call timeout to set up a play

questions.explanation: With 8 seconds left on the shot clock in a close game, get your best shot creator a touch in his preferred spot and let him work. Don't settle for a bad shot, but trust your best player to make something happen.

questions.scenario: Your team is down 3 points with 45 seconds left. You have the ball with a full shot clock.
questions.question: How do you manage this possession?

options.text: Attack immediately for a quick 3-pointer
Work for a good 2-pointer to cut the lead to 1
Use most of the shot clock, then take a 3-pointer
Drive for 2 and foul on defense immediately

questions.explanation: Down 3 with 45 seconds, you likely need a 3-pointer to tie. Use most of the shot clock (30+ seconds) to work for the best possible 3-point shot. Don't give them too much time if you score, but don't rush the shot either.

questions.scenario: End of the first quarter, your team has the ball with 18 seconds left, leading by 5 points.
questions.question: What's your approach for this possession?

options.text: Hold for the last shot of the quarter
Run your normal offense
Work for a quick good shot
Dribble out the clock

questions.explanation: With 18 seconds and a 5-point lead in the first quarter, run your normal offense. It's too early in the game to hold for one shot, and you don't want to waste a possession. Take a good shot when it comes.

questions.scenario: Your team is up 2 points with 35 seconds left and the shot clock at 20 seconds.
questions.question: What's your clock management strategy?

options.text: Use all 20 seconds then take any available shot
Look for a good shot but don't force it
Work for the best possible shot with 8-10 seconds left
Get a shot off by the 15-second mark

questions.explanation: Up 2 with 35 seconds left, work the shot clock down to 8-10 seconds before shooting. This limits their time if you miss, but still gives you time to get a good shot and potentially get an offensive rebound.

questions.scenario: Halftime is approaching with 8 seconds left. Your team is down 1 and has the ball at half court after a timeout.
questions.question: What's your mindset for this possession?

options.text: Get any shot off - a bad shot is better than no shot
Work for a 3-pointer to take the lead into halftime
Look for your best shooter in his sweet spot
Drive to the rim for a high-percentage shot

questions.explanation: With 8 seconds from half court, get the ball to your best shooter in his preferred spot and let him work. This is about shot quality and having your most reliable shooter take the attempt. Don't force a drive with limited time.

matchup-exploitation.description: Identifying size mismatches, speed advantages, foul trouble, and game flow management

questions.scenario: The opposing team's best defender just picked up his 4th foul with 8 minutes left in the game.
questions.question: How should this change your approach?

options.text: Attack him immediately to try to foul him out
Avoid him completely since he'll be playing more aggressively
Test him early, then attack if he's playing passive
Wait until later in the game to exploit his foul trouble

questions.explanation: With 4 fouls, test him early to see how aggressive he's playing. If he's backing off to avoid his 5th foul, attack him. If he's still playing physical, you can exploit that too by drawing the 5th foul through smart drives.

questions.scenario: A much slower big man gets switched onto you on the perimeter during a pick-and-roll.
questions.question: What's your best move?

options.text: Drive immediately before help can come
Pull up for a 3-pointer over him
Back him down in the post
Pass to reset and avoid the mismatch

questions.explanation: Speed vs. size is usually won by speed. Attack immediately with your first step before help defense can rotate. The big man can't stay with you laterally, and you should get to the rim or draw a foul.

questions.scenario: You notice the opposing point guard is getting tired after playing 35+ minutes and his defensive intensity is dropping.
questions.question: How do you take advantage of his fatigue?

options.text: Push the pace to make him work harder
Post him up to use his tiredness against him
Run more pick-and-rolls to make him work
All of the above

questions.explanation: When a defender is tired, attack in multiple ways: push pace to make him run more, use screens to make him work harder, and exploit his decreased lateral quickness. Make him defend you in space and wear him down further.

questions.scenario: Your team's center has a significant size advantage, but the opposing team keeps sending double teams whenever he touches the ball.
questions.question: How do you help exploit this size mismatch?

options.text: Keep feeding him the ball and let him work through the double
Space the floor better so he has more room to work
Look for the open man when the double team comes
Run different plays that don't involve the post

questions.explanation: When they double your big man, someone is getting left open. Your job is to recognize who gets left behind when the double comes and get them the ball quickly for an open shot. Turn their help into your advantage.

questions.scenario: The other team has a shot blocker who's altering shots at the rim, but he's not quick enough to defend pick-and-rolls on the perimeter.
questions.question: What's your strategy to neutralize his rim protection?

options.text: Avoid driving to the rim entirely
Use pick-and-rolls to pull him away from the basket
Attack him one-on-one to show you're not scared
Focus on outside shooting only

questions.explanation: If he's a rim protector but struggles on pick-and-rolls, force him to defend in space. Run pick-and-rolls that pull him out of the paint, then attack the rim when he's out of position or take open shots when he drops back.
